scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains manuscripts of two poems and an essay on France by Arthur Sherburne Hardy. Letters discuss the lack of a correspondent's reply to a request for an autograph of [Helen?] Keller for her majesty, and the correct usage of the religious term "mass," and include an invitation, and a note of thanks.
Correspondents include [Luther Halsey?] Gulick and a Dr. Leeds.

did.unittitle: Poem beginning "O what a night for a soul to go . . . " 1891 Mar. 11
Poem: "Immortality" beginning "My window is the open sky . . . " n. d.

scopecontent.p: Essay of personal reflections on the history and beauties of France.

did.unittitle: Arthur Sherburne Hardy to "Dear Sir" 1914 Sep. 12

scopecontent.p: Regrets lack of his correspondent's reply to his request for an autograph of Miss [Helen?] Keller for "Her Majesty."

did.unittitle: A. S. H. to [Luther Halsey?] Gulick 1917 Mar. 8

scopecontent.p: Invites Gulick to tea, and reports that Prof. [Frank Moore?] Colby is in town.

did.unittitle: A. S. H. to Dr. Leeds n. y. Mar. 17

scopecontent.p: [Thanks for note from Leeds in time of need.]
